item.title: Cloud environments
item.description:
→ The outsourcing of IT services and infrastructure, making them accessible remotely via the internet.
→ The internet is the infrastructure, and the world wide web is a service that runs on it.


These are used by a range of end-users. They can be accessed through a digital device (with internet). A public cloud is usually hosted by one cloud provider, e.g., Amazon Web Service, OneDrive.

These are used by a specific organisation and can be hosted on site or remotely. Access to a private cloud is restricted by a firewall managed by the organisation. A private cloud requires the organisation to install the hardware, software and networking components.

This is a cloud designed for and used by a group of organisations in a particular sector. For example, the financial sector may use a community cloud to transfer money between banks and process credit cards.

This is the 'best of both worlds' and incorporates the both private and public clouds. For example, an organisation can utilise some services on the public cloud, but has a private cloud for sensitive services or data.

Infrastructure as a Service (IaaS)

item.title: Virtualisation
item.description:
→ Remote servers accessed via the internet that store, manage and process data

→ This is the technology that enables a single, physical hardware system to be separated into multiple simulated environments.
Software know as a hypervisor e.g., VirtualBox, connects to the hardware and splits one system into separate systems known as Virtual Machines (VMs).
The hardware that is equipped with a hypervisor is called the host, and the VMs are called guests.



→ Increased security; a VM manager can control the guest’s programs. This mitigates the risk for harmful operations being carried out.
→ Management; the sharing and aggregation of data can all be managed from a central server.
→ Isolation; guests each have a separate environment . This reduces the risk of harmful operations and potential for collisions with other software.
→ Portability; a guest is packaged into a virtual image , this means it can be safely moved and executed on top of different VMs.

Benefits
→ Efficient use of hardware; many organisations only use a fraction of their hardware effectively, with virtualisation, multiple instances of hardware can be created and therefore increase effectiveness of the resources.
→ Continuous availability; virtualisation allows access at any time. A virtual instance can be moved from one server location to another without having to shut down the process. No data is losing during the migration process.
→ Simplified and faster setup; setting up systems can be complex and time-consuming. With virtualisation, an organisation can be up and running within minutes.
Drawbacks
→ Cost; initial setup can be costly as high performance hardware and software can be expensive.
→ Reduces performance; resources are shared. As there may be multiple users performing complex tasks, the overall performance can be reduces.
→ Security risks; a single compromised virtual machine could affect the others on the same host.
→ Downtime; hardware failures can impact multiple virtual machines on the same server.

item.description:

In this phase, the goals and objectives of the program are defined. Once an understanding of the program requirements has been achieved, a plan can be developed. This includes the identification of resources and determining of the budget for the project. This is also known as the feasibility study.

During this phase, the requirements for the program are analysed. An example of this is the identifying of stakeholders and their needs and expectations.

The program’s architecture and design are developed. The design of the program refers the program’s components, interfaces and how the program will be tested and deployed. Methods for designing the program can be through the use of structure charts, flowcharts and pseudocode. These help in designing the logic of the program without having to focus on the syntax.

Throughout this phase the program is developed and coded. One the program code has been completed, any necessary documentation is created. Documentation will include the flowcharts, pseudocode or structure charts from the design phase as well as in-depth explanations of the program’s functionality and program features.  This process will be taking the flowcharts or pseudocode from the Design phase and translating in into the proper program code.

The program is tested to ensure that it meets the requirements set in the planning phase. Examples of testing could be processes such as testing data inputs, both correct and incorrect data. People who do not have any involvement with the program may be brought in to use the program, this can aid in finding any bugs. These tests can be continued until the program is free of bugs. This is the debugging process.

item.title: Top-Down
item.description:
The top-down approach in software development is a method of designing and building a system by starting with a high-level design and then progressively refining the design with increasing levels of detail. This approach involves breaking down a large, complex problem or system into smaller, more manageable pieces, and then working on each piece individually.


High-level design: Top-down approach begins with a high-level understanding of the system’s requirements and functionality.
Decomposition: The system is broken down into smaller more manageable modules which are designed and implemented separately.
Stepwise refinement: Each module is refined in detail


Easier to understand
Improved organization
Reduced complexity
Faster development


Risk of oversimplification (the high-level design may not capture all the complexities of the system)
Difficulty in handling unexpected issues (top-down approach has a lack of flexibility)
Less creative


C
COBOL
FORTRAN


Click me!
The top-down approach goes from the general to the specific, whereas the bottom-up approach moves from the specific to the general.
During the top-down approach, integration happens after the high-level design is completed, whereas during bottom-up approach, the integration occurs as each component is developed and tested.
Top-down approach uses decomposition, which is taking the high level design and breaking down the system into more detail components…
Whereas Bottom-Up approach uses composition which is starting with the low-level components or modules first.
